thread.title: Chatham Commission to take up police salaries Friday
thread.title_full: Chatham Commission to take up police salaries Friday | savannahnow.com

author: KELLY QUIMBY
title: Chatham Commission to take up police salaries Friday
text:
By KELLY QUIMBY Chatham County commissioners on Friday are expected take up a unanimous recommendation from the Savannah-Chatham police policy committee to contribute more than $279,000 to salary increases for metro police.
According to agenda documents released Wednesday, the cost would be in addition to the $14.15 million payment for police service approved by the county commission when it voted in favor of a new police merger agreement with the city of Savannah last month.
Like the rest of the Savannah-Chatham police expenses, county staff are proposing using dollars from the fund supported by taxes from the unincorporated area, the special service district, to cover the increase.
“Any additional appropriations for police services such as the one recommended are not budgeted,” Assistant County Manager Linda Cramer wrote in her memo to county commissioners. “An appropriation of fund balance from the (special service district) fund will be required.”
A vote in favor of the increased salaries could be the last push needed to break the police merger logjam. The Savannah City Council has yet to act on the agreement approved by the county commission Sept. 11.
In that version, commissioners removed language that specifically addressed pay raises and added a line that requires any additional costs be recommended to both bodies by the Police Policy Committee, which is made up of the mayor of Savannah, the Chatham County commission chairman and the managers of both governments.
Addressing the change at a city council meeting the week after the county’s vote, City Manager Stephanie Cutter said she didn’t know whether the two governments were still on the same page.
In the weeks that followed, letters were exchanged and commission Chairman Al Scott paid a visit to the city council to show his support for the county’s participation in the raises.
At the commission’s last meeting, Oct. 9, Scott announced that the policy committee would meet to discuss police salaries the following week. The short policy committee meeting that followed resulted in the unanimous recommendation from the four members that Chatham County pay $279,773.92, or 24.27 percent, toward the pay increases to cover the period from July 1 to Dec. 31.
Scott said Wednesday he didn’t believe a police merger agreement hinged on the county’s support of the salaries, but he did support contributing the additional funds.
“We should support the salary increases, and that’s my recommendation on it,” Scott said. “I decided to put it on the agenda sooner rather than later. I don’t want to send a message to our combined metro force that the county is not on board with their pay increases. I think that would be an awful signal to send, and I hope my colleagues on the county commission would share my views.”
According to agenda documents, the vote would not address covering salaries through 2016. Scott said the two governments will do an end-of-year review to determine how much the county should contribute in the coming year.
IF YOU GO
What: Chatham County Commission meeting
When: 9:30 a.m. Friday
Where: County Commission Chambers, 2nd Floor, 124 Bull St.
